Adverse Media Combiner

Problem we are trying to solve here has been described here. This implementation recycles the code in 2 previous repos:

  • an old implementation
  • a cleaned up version of the old the implementation

pip

The library can be installed in the usual way using pip:

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Replicate our results with conda

We also provide a conda environment (am_combiner.yml) where all necessary packages/ development tools have been listed. The idea here is to give you a quick way to get started and to reproduce the results you see on our notebooks on your local machine. In order to use conda to run our code, follow the following steps (in your terminal):

  1. create an empty environment called am_combiner:
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}
  1. update your environment using the yaml file:
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}
  1. activate your environment:
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Now you can run, jupyter server, run the code and replicate our results. If you want to extend our conda environment and install extra packages, always prefer a conda install worklow. Chances are the conda-forge will already have a built recipe for the package you want. For example, if one needs to install jupyter_server, he could simple type (inside the activated environment):

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

If you are a developer and think other developer may benefit from the modification you made to the environment, you could update the yaml file in the following way:

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Note that the grep part is just a hack to avoid exporting the environment prefix (specific to the local machine) which may creates conflicts with version control.

Replicate our results with 'docker'

You can also replicate our results using docker. A self contained image has been provided. Note that this image will fire up a jupyter instance as soon as it starts.

You can build it in the usual way. Assuming we want to tag it am_combiner, you can use the following command on your terminal:

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

In order to run, you can first fire up the docker image:

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Then, copy one of the links shown on your terminal in your browser and start using jupyter notebook as usual.

Data

The current implementation relies on a number of csv files. We suggest to save them all in a Google drive folder. Ideally, we should migrate these files to an S3 bucket later but in order to keep everything in the same place, Google drive could be a good starting point.
